explanation: The report is correct. OS_strnlen is implemented as a thin wrapper around memchr(s, 0, maxlen) with maxlen == OS_MAX_PATH_LEN. If the caller supplies a VirtualPath that does not contain a '\0' within the first OS_MAX_PATH_LEN bytes and the underlying object is actually smaller than OS_MAX_PATH_LEN (for example a char buf[8] with no terminating NUL), memchr will attempt to read up to maxlen bytes and thus may read past the end of the object -> undefined behavior. memchr is a <string.h> function and this behavior falls squarely under MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 (string.h functions must not access beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters). The code neither enforces nor verifies that the pointed-to object is at least OS_MAX_PATH_LEN bytes long nor that a NUL exists within the object bounds before calling memchr, so the rule is violated.
